just a quick update - I've added some stuff to the API
Mark all as read: https://convore.com/api/#account-mark-read
Mark topic as read: https://convore.com/api/#topic-mark-read
Members online (all members in your groups): https://convore.com/api/#account-online
that should be all the major updates for a while... so let me know if you need anything else soonish
Pagination for messages (using an until_id): https://convore.com/api/#topic-messages
The API changes so fast, I am constantly updating my wrapper classes. :)

and no need to apologize, long days all around I expect :-)

@leah - to clarify, *not* asking for a list of group_ids that the authenticated user is a member of (because that's satisfied by /groups). *am* asking for each user returned in account/online to include an array of group_ids

@protocool that's a pretty expensive database operation (getting all the groups for all the users in groups you share). What's the use case in the UI?
I think we may be misunderstanding each other. "all groups for all users in groups you share" does indeed sound expensive. I'm talking about *online* only. <more>
it's probably best to just request the group members online as it's needed (if possible)
which I guess isn't too bad
heh
it can get up there during the day though
it's not a killer, I can ask each group for /online
@protocool yeah, that's what the website does obviously.
because that's totally different from campfire
@mridley I'm just curious how the topics are handled

@leah Question about the pagination for messages.  I'm not sure how best to use until_id because the id of messages doesn't increment by one each time so I can't do addition and subtraction of the message id based on some pagination messages per page count.  Also there is no from_id so apparently a call for the messages for page n will return the messages from pages 1...n as well?  Maybe I'm missing something obvious?
@mridley in case you haven't figured it out (assuming topics and messages work the same btw), the message id you specify in "until_id" is the *oldest* message you have cached in memory.

The payload you get back will have at least one message (unless it's deleted I guess, not tested that) which is the message specified by your until_id. All subsequent messages in the payload are the messages that are *older* (descending order) than the one you specified in until_id.
Note that I'm basing my description on the behavior of paginating through topics though - I haven't bothered implementing paged message fetching yet.
sorry, I've been offline for a bit
the api also just gives you the until_id to use for the next page

It might just be a concept bias I have since whenever I have written pagination APIs I have had the arguments be a starting id and a count of how many to return.  So this is a little different.  I'm sure I'll figure it out if I play with it some more.

Thanks for the input @protocool and @leah  I ended up doing the pagination the old fashioned way where I grab all the messages each time and only output what's relevant for the page but that's wasteful.  I'm still not 100% sure I follow how to use until_id but I will play with it some more and see if I can figure it out.
